column8: U.S. mistakenly granted citizenship to hundreds of immigrants

column2:
The pressure is on Hillary Clinton.

Insiders in both parties agree: Clinton, having lost most of her lead over the past few weeks and bringing more experience to the stage, faces higher expectations than Donald Trump when the two square off for the first debate on Long Island.

Story Continued Below

That鈥檚 according to The POLITICO Caucus 鈥?a panel of activists, strategists and operatives in 11 key battleground states. Roughly equal percentages of Democrats (69 percent) and Republicans (74 percent) said Clinton is under more pressure to perform than Trump. But Democrats mostly lamented the low expectations for Trump, a relative political neophyte who has exhibited little command of the issues.

鈥淪he shouldn't be [under more pressure], but so long as he avoids standing on stage and vomiting on himself, the press will give Trump a glowing review,鈥?said a Nevada Democrat 鈥?who, like all respondents, completed the survey anonymously. 鈥淗illary will need a strong performance to demonstrate that she passes and Trump fails the commander-in-chief test.鈥?
鈥淭he media and Trump himself have set the bar too low for Trump,鈥?a New Hampshire Democrat added. 鈥淧residents don't get graded on a curve, and candidates in debates shouldn't be either.鈥?
One Ohio Democrat detected a double standard for the first female major-party nominee.

鈥淗illary Clinton has spent a public lifetime of being held to a strikingly different standard, and this debate will be no exception,鈥?said the Ohio Democrat. 鈥淪he will have to answer every single question flawlessly, exude gravitas, look presidential, channel Bill's and Barack's oratorical mastery, not raise her voice, not cough, wear an acceptable pantsuit, smile enough, be likable, not laugh and have a good hair day. Donald Trump will just have to show up.鈥?
Republicans also said Clinton was under greater scrutiny on Monday night, but for different reasons: tightening polls that show Trump eclipsing Clinton in some battleground states.

鈥淪omehow she needs to reverse the trend,鈥?said an Ohio Republican. 鈥淣ever seen anyone do it before. This will be her chance 鈥?and maybe her last chance.鈥?
鈥淪he has to stop [Trump鈥檚] momentum with a strong debate performance, and she has to be able to stand on the stage for 90 minutes and look healthy for 90 minutes or the whole issue of her health comes back with a vengeance,鈥?added a Virginia Republican. 鈥淎ll [Trump] has to do is not say anything racist or sexist and look like he could be president.鈥?
Among those insiders who said Trump was under more pressure 鈥?31 percent of Democrats and 26 percent of Republicans 鈥?most pointed to the GOP nominee鈥檚 volatile personality.

鈥淗illary Clinton is expected to do well. She is a policy wonk,鈥?said a Michigan Republican. 鈥淭he pressure is on Donald Trump not to lose his cool. He has been doing very well in his public appearances, but that is with the assistance of a TelePrompTer. He will have no such help at the debate, and if I were coaching Hillary Clinton, I would be encouraging her to get him as riled up as possible. To win the debate, all Trump really needs to do is meet expectations, keep his cool, and look presidential.鈥?
鈥淭he question we are all waiting to have answered is: Can he be serious?鈥?added a Michigan Democrat. 鈥淐an he answer questions directly? How will he react (or overreact) when he is directly challenged? Can he control his temper?鈥?
Two other takeaways from the pre-debate survey:

Most insiders expect Clinton to 鈥渨in鈥?the debate.

Majorities in both parties peg Clinton as most likely to be the victor on Monday night: 76 percent of Democrats and 59 percent of Republicans.

鈥淢edia look at who best answered questions, and that will likely be Hillary,鈥?said an Iowa Republican.

鈥淸Clinton鈥檚] mastery of issues and policies and no-nonsense delivery will prevail over bluster, name-calling and promises that can never be kept,鈥?added a New Hampshire Democrat.

But not all Democrats were so optimistic about Clinton 鈥?or the media through which voters will interpret the debate.

鈥淭he press wants Trump to win,鈥?said a Florida Democrat. 鈥淭heir disdain for her, plus desire to keep the race alive, means unless he really screws up, they'll give him the win on the most absurd grade curve ever.鈥?
Some Republicans also claimed media bias 鈥?in the other direction.

鈥淭he media has never been more in the tank for a candidate in modern history: CNN, NBC, ABC and POLITICO will all say she won,鈥?a Virginia Republican said. 鈥淏ut then again everyone also 'knew' that Carter beat Reagan in their debate as well.鈥?
Insiders think the debate will matter.

Asked whether they expect the debate to have a significant impact on the race, most insiders in both parties think it will generate momentum for one of the candidates.

Among Democratic insiders, 66 percent believe Clinton will benefit from the debate, 11 percent think Trump will get a bounce and 23 percent don鈥檛 expect the debate to move the needle.

鈥淭rump will flounder, ramble and lie (because he always does),鈥?a Michigan Democrat predicted. 鈥淭he moderators will challenge him, and he'll get mad. He'll complain afterwards that they picked on him and favored Hillary. First impressions are hard to shake off, and this won't go well for him.鈥?
The numbers were flipped for Republicans, with slightly less enthusiasm for the GOP standard-bearer: 52 percent think the debate will help Trump, 26 percent think it will help Clinton and 22 percent said it wouldn鈥檛 have a significant impact.

鈥淭rump has the most to gain by appearing presidential and even-tempered,鈥?said a New Hampshire Republican. 鈥淗e does that successfully, and he cuts into Hillary's greatest strength.鈥?
But some Republicans said Clinton could stunt Trump鈥檚 momentum with a strong performance Monday night.

鈥淚f she pins his ears back, [it helps her],鈥?said an Iowa Republican. 鈥淚f it's a draw, it's a net negative for her. She has to have something to stop his momentum. She's got to hit him with a brick.鈥?
Other insiders, however, doubted whether the debate would have a significant, permanent effect on the race.

鈥淲e're past the era of the big debate swings: the bloodless Dukakis death penalty answer, the Reagan age quip, the Bentsen 'you're no John Kennedy' moments,鈥?an Iowa Republican said. 鈥淪wing voters are like the California Condor, a critically endangered species disappearing at an alarming rate. Opinion media, partisan polarization, and two highly unpopular candidates make this a battle over a very small group of voters in about a dozen states, and whatever bounce comes out of this debate will dissipate as quickly as it appears.鈥?
Added a Florida Democrat: 鈥淒oes a damn thing matter this year? I think not.鈥?
These are the members of The POLITICO Caucus, not all of whom participated in this special survey:

column8: Insiders: The heat is on Hillary

column2:
Posted by Frank Wilkenmeyer on 19 Sep 2016

Donald Trump Jr. Is quite possibly the dumbest person ever to take to social media. In the very least, it鈥檚 a tossup between him and little brother Eric, who just yesterday made a fool of himself with his childish self-admiration for being the answer to a crossword puzzle question, along with free wifi, pushup bras and Bozo the Clown.

Together, the dimwitted duo provide enough social media fodder to make fun of them well into the next generation with posts to spare. When this election is finally over, it will be almost sad to see them fade back into oblivion. Maybe we鈥檒l keep track of their Twitter accounts just for a giggle every now and then.

Today鈥檚 silliness begins with Oompa Loompa Jr. pinning a tweet that is certainly relevant to a particularly volatile national discussion happening right now: Colin Kaepernick and the National Anthem. As more and more athletes decide to take a knee in protest to support Black Lives Matter, more and more conservatives trash them for it, calling them unpatriotic and demanding they stop getting media coverage. Lord Cheeto II has been one of the most vocal, accusing Kaepernick of disrespecting our troops and those who died for his freedom.

For the left, it鈥檚 a simple matter of the 1st Amendment. Regardless of how you feel about the issue, these athletes have the right to express themselves. Yes, that means from government oppression and prosecution and not public criticism, but let鈥檚 not forget that it鈥檚 people like Little Comb-Over who are calling for police to stop providing protection for these athletes, for their employers to terminate their contracts and some have even gone so far as to suggest they be jailed for treason.

For years, we鈥檝e known that the only constitutional amendment conservatives care about is the second, so when this tweet appeared pinned to Mini Douche鈥檚 Twitter account this morning, I couldn鈥檛 help but bust out in hysterical laughter:

Clearly when you鈥檙e the son of pure evil you have a hard time understanding the words you use. When 鈥渓iberals鈥?鈥?otherwise known as 鈥渟ane people鈥?鈥?try to explain why people like Kaepernick and those who have followed his lead are expressing that very right, we鈥檙e attacked in a frenzy of hate by people who think placing your hand over your heart and singing a song is mandatory patriotism. It鈥檚 not. The first amendment is exactly today what it was when the founders added it to the framework of a growing nation in 1789; the right to be you.

The Supreme Court has sided with those 鈥渓iberals鈥?every time the issue of free speech is tied to something conservatives think should be compulsory, like the pledge of allegiance and school prayer. I鈥檝e said it already once in this article and thousands of times in my everyday life and I鈥檒l say it again: The 2nd Amendment is the only one they see as absolute. All others are open to the interpretation of some holier than thou asshole like Donald Trump Jr.

Featured image by Gage Skidmore

column2:
Donald Trump's reputation for being always available to reporters is way out of date.

Trump is saying "yes" to Fox News almost every day but saying "no" to most other major networks and news organizations -- a highly unusual strategy for a presidential nominee.

He called into "Fox & Friends" on Monday morning, he is booked on "The O'Reilly Factor" Monday night, and he has another town hall with Sean Hannity coming up on Wednesday.

Rousing the base instead of reaching out to undecided voters may ultimately pay off for Trump. If nothing else, it limits the candidate's exposure to hard-hitting questions -- while fueling frustration among journalists.

Trump's surrogates continue to say that he is more accessible than Hillary Clinton, but that is no longer true.

Newt Gingrich knocked Clinton at a Trump rally on Monday afternoon by saying "she doesn't do press conferences." But Clinton has taken questions from reporters at half a dozen press conferences in the past two weeks, including as recently as Monday morning.

These sessions, while relatively short, have been plentiful, while Trump has not held a press conference since July.

Trump beat reporters are starting to make noise about the drought 鈥?especially since Trump made Clinton's eight-month period without press conferences into a major campaign talking point.

"It's been more than 50 days since Donald Trump held a press conference," David Martosko of The Daily Mail tweeted Monday.

Trump's recent TV appearances, on "The Dr. Oz Show" and "The Tonight Show," made news, but not in journalistic settings.

The Washington Post's Robert Costa had a newsmaking interview with Trump last week. But that's the exception to the rule. The New York Times last had an interview with Trump about a month ago.

Trump last appeared on CNN in late August. Because Anderson Cooper challenged Trump about the candidate's muddled stance on immigration, The Post's Callum Borchers concluded that "it didn't go very well" for Trump.

"It went so not well, in fact, that you have to wonder whether his campaign will decide it's best to dodge the likes of Anderson Cooper and Chuck Todd 鈥?or, for that matter, Chris Wallace and Bret Baier 鈥?and stick to softball sessions with Sean Hannity and the 'Fox & Friends' crew," Borchers wrote afterwards.

Trump's last time on NBC was the "Commander in Chief Forum" on September 7. Moderator Matt Lauer was widely criticized for his light touch with Trump.

Related: Behind the scenes, NBC execs concede Matt Lauer forum performance was "disaster"

The candidate's last time on ABC was a short interview with David Muir on September 6. His last time on CBS was a "60 Minutes" sit-down with Lesley Stahl on July 17.

Trump does have another CBS interview in the works, a campaign spokeswoman said.

TV networks are agitating for more interviews with both Trump and Clinton. The difference between the two is that Trump previously had a reputation for calling in to morning shows and sitting down with interviewers all the time.

This accessibility also once extended to his traveling press corps.

"Trump used to be very, very accessible to the press. At the beginning of his campaign, he was extremely accessible," CNN politics reporter Jeremy Diamond said on Sunday's "Reliable Sources." "You could catch him for quick interviews on the way in and out of rallies. And that has really changed."

Diamond said "he is less accessible I think, in many regards, than Hillary Clinton at this point."

Trump's campaign declined to comment Monday on its media strategy. Republican communications strategist Ron Bonjean said most candidates in Trump's position would be "trying to reach a a broader general election audience."

"However, most Americans already know Trump as a household name and he doesn't need to diversify his interviews for additional exposure," Bonjean said. "Trump is protecting himself from less friendly journalists while getting out his message at the same time even if it is to a more conservative audience."

This conservative-focused media strategy is also gaining attention among Trump's critics. "He pretty much exclusively appears on Fox News now," Judd Legum, editor of the liberal news site ThinkProgress, tweeted on Monday.

Trump's relationship with Hannity is perhaps the best symbol of how the candidate gets out his message on his own terms. Trump has taped numerous town halls with the conservative commentator.

According to TVNewser, Wednesday's town hall will focus on "issues and concerns surrounding African-Americans this election cycle."

According to Nielsen data, only 1.5% of Hannity's 2 million nightly viewers are African American. Overall, at any given time of day, about 2% of Fox News viewers are African American.

column2:
Pence gives no specifics on why Trump Foundation story is inaccurate

When it comes to the Trump campaign's allegations of "inaccuracies and omissions" against a Washington Post story, running mate Mike Pence struggled late Tuesday night to account for specific examples.

Appearing on MSNBC's "The 11th Hour with Brian Williams" after an evening rally in Williamsburg, Virginia, the Indiana governor backed up the Trump campaign's statement against the Post's reporting earlier in the day that Donald Trump spent $258,000 from his charitable foundation to settle legal issues.

Story Continued Below

"Well, I think what we found is that there is a number of factual errors in that story as there were in previous stories about the Trump Foundation. I'm confident they'll be able to address those and demonstrate that they fully complied with the law," Pence told Brian Williams, adding that the "larger issue" is the Clinton Foundation.

Williams tried to button up the issue, pressing Pence specifically for "what the factual errors are that the campaign is alleging" from the latest Post story.

"Well, I think the foundation will be able to lay those out. There were errors in the previous Washington Post stories, and, you know, look, you know me a while, Brian. I strongly support a free and independent press. People are entitled to ask questions, and I'm sure the Trump Foundation and the Trump family will continue to be able to answer those questions."

Pence's comments and the Trump campaign statement came hours after the latest article from the Post into the Republican nominee's charitable foundation.

column2:
As police today captured the man wanted for questioning in connection to a series of explosive devices in New York City and New Jersey, new information about him has begun to emerge.

The man, Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, was born in 1988 in Afghanistan and is a naturalized U.S. citizen, according to the FBI. He was discovered and captured in Linden, New Jersey, not far from his last known address in Elizabeth.

New Jersey State Police

A U.S. official initially told ABC News Rahami came to the U.S. in 2000, but his father later said the family came over in 1995. Court records indicate Ahmad Rahami was from a large family and may have as many as seven siblings.

Former classmates said he attended Edison High School in New Jersey.

One of them, Chris Konya, said Rahami was quiet but funny and a "pretty normal guy." Konya and another former classmate said Rahami had a child with his high school girlfriend.

Rahami was enrolled at Middlesex County College from fall of 2010 to fall of 2012, where he worked toward an associate's degree in criminal justice but did not graduate, according to school officials.

New Jersey State Police

The Rahami family owned a fried chicken restaurant in Elizabeth. An employee and a recent customer said Rahami worked there.

"I come in here every week or two, just to get something to eat," local resident Ryan McCann told The Associated Press. "He's always in there. He's a very friendly guy. That's what's so scary. It's hard when it's home."

Members of the Rahami family apparently did not get along well with the local police and sued several officers in 2011 for allegedly harassing them over purported violations related the restaurant's operation. The case was dismissed in 2012, pending the resolution of a related legal matter, according to documents.

Investigators are poring over Rahami's past travel, including what may have been a recent nearly year-long trip in which he flew to Quetta, Pakistan in April 2013 and returned to the U.S. through the United Arab Emirates in March 2014, according to the U.S. official. Rahami reported to authorities that he was visiting his wife and family, who he said were Afghan refugees living in Quetta, and that he had traveled by car between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

New Jersey State Police

In August 2014 Rahami was arrested after allegedly stabbing someone in the leg, according to court documents. A complaint filed by a police officer said the officer "has reason to believe that the person is a danger to himself, others or property," but Rahami was not indicted.

Today Rahami was shot at least once by police during an exchange of gunfire before he was captured and then taken to a local hospital, authorities said. He is not cooperating with investigators, even so far as refusing to give his name, according to a source briefed on the case. Officials said they have not determined a motive for the attacks.

Late Monday officials announced charges against Rahami related to the shootout with police: five counts of attempted murder, second-degree unlawful possession of a weapon and second-degree possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose. Bail has been set at $5.2 million. It is unclear if Rahami has an attorney.

A senior Afghan official told ABC News the Afghan government is ready to assist the U.S. in any way it can and is searching for any information it may have on Rahami.

New Jersey State Police

ABC News' Cindy Galli, Megan Christie, Randy Kreider, Alex Hosenball and Cho Park contributed to this report.

[Editor's Note Sept. 28, 2016: The original version of this report said that Ahmad Rahami came to the U.S. in 2000. Rahami's father later told ABC News, however, that his son and the family came in 1995 and that Rahami received his Green Card in 2000.]

column2:
CLEVELAND 鈥?Donald Trump campaigned Wednesday morning in a church in a historically African-American community and sold himself as the candidate who could fix the problems of urban America. Within hours, Trump was proposing a vast expansion of 鈥渟top-and-frisk鈥?policing policies that have proved explosively controversial in black communities for encouraging racial profiling.

It was just another day in Trump鈥檚 up-and-down black outreach campaign undertaken to wash away the stain of racism charges lobbed at him by Hillary Clinton and the Democrats.

Story Continued Below

The effort has taken Trump from a black church in inner-city Detroit earlier this month to addressing largely white audiences in rural North Carolina where, on Tuesday evening, he proclaimed in a small town named after a slaveholder that black communities "are absolutely in the worst shape that they鈥檝e ever been in before, ever, ever, ever."

On Wednesday, Trump hit the campaign trail with former boxing promoter Don King 鈥?who dropped the N-word before a group of pastors at a Cleveland church while extolling Trump as a 鈥済ladiator.鈥?King hailed Trump as the rare candidate who would overthrow the existing political system under which minorities have suffered.

鈥淭he system is the problem, and he鈥檚 the only gladiator that will take on the system,鈥?King said.

After the church event, Trump sat for a 鈥渢own hall鈥?with Fox News host and unabashed supporter Sean Hannity. Asked by an audience member what he would do to address 鈥渧iolence in the black community,鈥?Trump embraced stop-and-frisk.

鈥淲e did it in New York, it worked incredibly well,鈥?Trump said.

Fierce opposition to that policy in minority communities was among the issues that Bill de Blasio rode to prominence and, ultimately, the mayor鈥檚 office.

But even before Trump鈥檚 stop-and-frisk comments, he was taking heat for his 鈥渆ver, ever, ever鈥?remark Tuesday night.

鈥淚 don't know what Mr. Trump is talking about to say that the situation for African-Americans is worse than it's ever been,鈥?Rep. John Lewis, the Democratic civil rights icon, said Wednesday on MSNBC. 鈥淚s he talking about worse than slavery? Worse than the system of segregation and racial discrimination 鈥?when we couldn't take a seat at the lunch counter and be served? Worse than being denied the right to register to vote, to participate in the democratic process and live in certain neighborhoods and communities?鈥?
Trump鈥檚 polling numbers among African-American voters have been dismal 鈥?in the low single digits 鈥?and some believe his outreach to black voters is as much about convincing moderate white voters, particularly women and those in the suburbs, that he is not racist. Trump regularly brings up his outreach to blacks 鈥?鈥淲hat do you have to lose?鈥?he says 鈥?to largely white audiences.

At the New Spirit Revival Center in Cleveland, Trump assembled an eclectic kitchen cabinet of some of his closest advisers to attest to his beliefs before a diverse crowd.

Seated to Trump鈥檚 right was Mike Pence, his soft-spoken running mate. To his left, outspoken longtime attorney Michael Cohen. Behind him: King (鈥渢here鈥檚 only one,鈥?Trump said), former presidential rival Ben Carson (鈥渢ough鈥?, retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn (鈥渁 tough general鈥? and former "Apprentice" star Omarosa Manigault (鈥渁 wonderful woman鈥?, who has helped with Trump鈥檚 black outreach.

鈥淚鈥檓 different from a lot of Republicans, frankly,鈥?Trump said from the pulpit.

Trump, who has called himself the 鈥渓aw and order鈥?candidate, criticized the police officer who shot an unarmed black man in Oklahoma last week. Trump said he had watched the video and that the officer may have been 鈥渃hoking鈥?in the fatal shooting. Trump has mostly defended the police in such incidents.

"Now, did she get scared? Was she choking? What happened? But maybe people like that, people that choke, people that do that, maybe they can't be doing what they're doing, OK?鈥?
King, whom top GOP officials had pushed not to speak at the Republican National Convention due to a past manslaughter conviction, was given the prime slot of introducing Trump at a forum billed as a pastors leadership conference.

King, clothed in a sparkling jacket and clutching the flags of Israel and the United States, argued repeatedly that 鈥渢he system鈥?had oppressed minorities and women and only Trump can upend it entirely.

鈥淓very white woman should cast a vote for Donald Trump,鈥?said King, who also went on an extended riff about the struggles of African-Americans.

鈥淚 told Michael Jackson, I said if you're poor, you're a poor Negro 鈥?I would use the N-word 鈥?but if you rich, you are a rich Negro; if you are intelligent, intellectual, you're an intellectual Negro; if you're a dancing and sliding and gliding n-----, I mean, Negro,鈥?King said.

When Trump took his turn at the pulpit minutes later, he grinned, 鈥淎h, there鈥檚 only one Don King.鈥?
Before King, Cohen, Trump鈥檚 attorney, used his time at the church to slash at the 鈥渄isgusting, liberal, mainstream media鈥?and its casting of Trump as a 鈥渞acist.鈥?
鈥淭he word of the 2016 election has somehow become 鈥榬acist,鈥欌€?Cohen complained. 鈥淚鈥檝e lost count as to how many times the disgusting, liberal, mainstream media have attempted to label Mr. Donald Trump as racist, a xenophobe and a bigot. And let鈥檚 not forget, sexist, misogynist, narcissist, Islamophobe, anti-Hispanic, anti-Semite demagogue. And countless others. It鈥檚 disgraceful.鈥?
Cohen said, 鈥淣ot only is Donald Trump not a racist, he believes that all people are part of one race: the human race.鈥?
Trump insisted that Democrats had abandoned black voters, and that he wouldn鈥檛.

鈥淭hey come and they take your vote,鈥?Trump said, 鈥渁nd they say they鈥檒l see you in four years.鈥?

column2:
鈥淗e didn鈥檛 say the document was legitimate," Joe Arpaio said of Donald Trump's recent announcement. | Getty Joe Arpaio: Trump didn鈥檛 call Obama鈥檚 birth certificate 鈥榣egitimate鈥?
Donald Trump finally acknowledged President Barack Obama鈥檚 American birthplace last week, but one of his supporters, controversial Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio, sees a silver lining for the "birther" movement: Trump didn't take a position on whether Obama鈥檚 birth certificate was forged.

鈥淚f he says the president was born here, maybe he has information I don鈥檛 have,鈥?Arpaio told POLITICO of the GOP nominee's statement. 鈥淗e didn鈥檛 say the document was legitimate. He didn鈥檛 go that route.鈥?
Story Continued Below

Of Trump鈥檚 statement on Obama鈥檚 birthplace, Arpaio added: 鈥淚t didn鈥檛 bother me.鈥?
Arpaio, a prominent Trump supporter known for his hard-line views on immigration, opened an investigation into the legitimacy of Obama鈥檚 birth certificate in August 2011, several months after the White House published it online, further demonstrating that he was, in fact, born in Hawaii.

Trump rose to political prominence in part through insinuating, falsely, that Obama was not born in the United States 鈥?a claim the president鈥檚 supporters have long decried as racist. He backed down from it under pressure last week, in a short statement at an otherwise drawn-out press conference at his new luxury hotel in Washington. Trump also attempted to blame his opponent, Hillary Clinton, for starting the rumor, another claim independent fact checkers have debunked.

But while Trump has sought to sidestep the birther issue, Arpaio has refused to back down from his own claim that Obama鈥檚 birth certificate was forged. On Tuesday in Phoenix, Arpaio addressed the conservative group that requested he investigate the document, saying that 鈥渨e are looking at a forged document. Period.鈥?
On Wednesday, Arpaio told POLITICO the investigation into the document is ongoing. He declined to detail what evidence that effort has turned up, but he claimed that his office has found nothing 鈥渢o say it鈥檚 a legitimate document.鈥?
Arpaio also tried to separate himself from the birther movement, arguing that his investigation is focused on the document itself, rather than the president鈥檚 birthplace, and denied that his skepticism is motivated by racism.

Still, he would not say that he believes Obama was born in the U.S.

鈥淚 have no idea now where he was born,鈥?Arpaio said. 鈥淵ou hear a lot of stories.鈥?
He and Trump did not discuss the birth certificate issue before the nominee held the press conference last week, Arpaio said.

鈥淚 didn鈥檛 know he was going to say it,鈥?he said.

column2:
Story highlights Obama has taken steps toward solidifying the alliance with Israel this month

His meeting with Netanyahu was likely to be their last face-to-face consultations

New York (CNN) President Barack Obama confronted one of his most strained foreign partnerships Wednesday during a final meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the pair making a last attempt at patching up their stormy bond before Obama leaves office.

Speaking before their session, Obama said he was aiming to ascertain the prospects for peace in the region as he prepares to end his presidency.

"Our hope will be that in these conversations we get the sense of how Israel sees the next few years, what the opportunities are and what the challenges are in order to ensure we keep alive the possibility of a stable, secure Israel at peace with its neighbors," Obama said. "These are challenging times. One thing that I would say about Prime Minister Netanyahu is that he is always very candid with us."

That candor has become a hallmark of the relationship between Obama and his Israeli counterpart, whom the White House has accused of being less-than-diplomatic in expressing his opposition to US policies like the nuclear agreement with Iran. Obama's 30-minute meeting Wednesday with Netanyahu was likely to be their final opportunity for face-to-face consultations before a new president enters the Oval Office in January.

Obama is intent on conferring solid ties with Israel upon his successor, despite the personal animus that developed between him and Netanyahu, as he looks to boost the relationship during the homestretch of a presidential campaign in which he hopes to see Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton prevail.

column2:
Story highlights Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe was photographed with Willie Nelson, and Nelson's marijuana

Nelson was in Bristow Saturday for a Farm Aid 2016 concert

(CNN) Hanging out with Willie Nelson over the weekend has left a cloud around Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, after a photo of McAuliffe and the legendary marijuana-loving musician tweeted by Nelson's wife, Annie Nelson, included a can of "Willie's Reserve" -- Nelson's brand of weed.

It's sold in Colorado and is legal in Washington, but not Virginia -- a reality Annie Nelson might have been alluding to when she captioned the picture: ""UH-OH Trouble!"

McAuliffe spokesman Brian Coy told the Richmond Times-Dispatch that the Democratic governor has never used drugs in his life -- and isn't cool enough to know what Willie's Reserve is.

"He was not and still is not aware of whatever was on the table or anywhere around him and wouldn't know marijuana or related paraphernalia if it walked up and shook his hand," Coy said. "He's cool, but he's not that cool."

The newspaper's political reporter, Graham Moomaw, tweeted a zoomed-in photo of the can of Willie's Reserve weed, next to a pair of glasses and a remote control.

Let's enhance https://t.co/cmmucUKRTT pic.twitter.com/7YlX5za85l 鈥?Graham Moomaw (@gmoomaw) September 19, 2016

column8: McAuliffe hangs with Willie Nelson -- and his weed

column2:
In March, in a bold 鈥淥h yeah?鈥?moment during an interview with the Washington Post鈥檚 editorial board, Donald Trump took the paper鈥檚 dare and revealed, then and there, his very short list of foreign policy advisers. There were just five, though he said, 鈥淚 have quite a few more.鈥?The list was a head-scratcher, a random assortment of obscure and questionable pundits. One of the names, offered without elaboration, was, 鈥淐arter Page, PhD.鈥?
Who?

Story Continued Below

Reporters quickly Googling found that Page is the founder and managing partner of an investment fund called Global Energy Capital, and that he claims to have years of experience investing in Russia and the energy sector. As for his connection to Trump, when Page was reached for comment by the New York Times the day after Trump鈥檚 big reveal, he said he had been sending policy memos to the campaign and the paper said he 鈥渨ill be advising Mr. Trump on energy policy and Russia.鈥?
This piqued my interest: I have been a Russia wonk for most of my adult life, I spent years living and reporting from Moscow, still go there regularly for reporting trips, and am in touch with lots of friends there. And yet, despite the tightly knit nature of the expat business community in Russia, no one I spoke to had ever heard of Carter Page.

鈥淲hat鈥檚 this guy鈥檚 name?鈥?says one former Western energy CEO who spent years in Russia, and would have overlapped there with Page.

鈥淚 had not heard of Carter Page before it came out in the media,鈥?says another prominent Western businessman who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades. 鈥淏ut I am getting a lot of emails from friends asking, 鈥楬ave you heard of this guy?鈥欌€?
鈥淪trangely, I've never heard of Carter Page until this Trump connection,鈥?Bill Browder responded to me in an email. He was one of the biggest Western players in the Russian market until President Vladimir Putin turned on him and Browder became his fierce critic. 鈥淚t's odd, because I've heard of every other financier who was a player on Moscow at the time.鈥?
Someone, apparently, has heard of him: On Friday, Yahoo News reported that Page was being probed by U.S. intelligence for purported back-channel ties to Russian leaders. The story resurfaced the name of a character who鈥檇 all but vanished from the campaign, and reawakened questions about who, exactly, Trump was surrounding himself with.

This has been a concern swirling around the outsider candidate since he began, a real-estate developer with almost no serious Washington connections to tap for advice. 鈥淚鈥檓 going to surround myself only with the best and most serious people," Trump famously told a Post reporter last summer about how he would staff his campaign. "We want top-of-the-line professionals.鈥?As the primaries unfolded, it became increasingly obvious that Trump would need all the top-of-the-line help he could get when it came to foreign policy. In an interview with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt, Trump confused the Kurds with the Iranian Al-Quds Force, couldn鈥檛 tell the difference between Hezbollah and Hamas, and couldn鈥檛 recognize the name of the leader of ISIS. (In his defense, Trump said that 鈥淗ugh was giving me name after name, Arab name, Arab name, and there are few people anywhere, anywhere, that would have known those names.鈥? The Republican foreign policy specialists who would normally be a brain trust began slamming him in the press or publicly signing on to anti-Trump manifestos. And since they increasingly were fleeing the candidate, who were the people who would line up to advise him instead? What would they be like?

Enter Carter Page, a 44-year-old Ph.D., and business school graduate who claims an expertise in Russia and energy, yet who, I quickly discovered, was known by neither Russia experts nor energy experts nor Russian energy experts. (鈥淚 can poll any number of people involved in energy in Russia about Carter Page and they鈥檒l say, 鈥楥arter who? You mean Jimmy Carter?鈥欌€?says one veteran Western investor in Russian energy.) Page also, as I would be surprised to discover, appears largely unknown to Trump鈥檚 own campaign.

What I did find, however, is that while Page might not be helping Trump, Trump has been a significant help to Page. Since being named by Trump as an adviser, Page, who has spent his career trying to put together energy deals in Russia and the former Soviet Union, has finally begun to be noticed in the region. He is being treated in Russia as a person with potentially important ties in America. 鈥淗e鈥檚 an extremely well-informed, authoritative expert on Russia,鈥?says Mikhail Leontiev, a pro-Kremlin talking head and spokesman for Rosneft, Russia鈥檚 state oil giant. 鈥淧eople really respect him in this industry. He鈥檚 a very serious guy, and he has a good reputation.鈥?According to the Yahoo report, U.S. intelligence believes Page had an audience with top Russian officials鈥攊ncluding Rosneft head Igor Sechin鈥攄uring a summer trip to Moscow. From what I could find about him, it鈥檚 hard to imagine he could have secured those meetings without that mention by Trump.

Page has also been the subject of some breathless coverage in the American press. A March Bloomberg profile touted his 鈥渄eep ties鈥?with 鈥渆xecutives at Gazprom,鈥?the state-owned Russian gas giant, whom he says he advised on some of its biggest deals of the past decade. Last month, the Post ran a piece that was breathless in a different way, casting him as a shadowy broker with potentially important ties in Russia, some of them unsavory. The Yahoo story also portrays Page as a well-connected, high-rolling businessman with 鈥渆xtensive business interests in Russia鈥?and an office 鈥渁round the corner from Trump Tower.鈥?
Page has fueled all this by making some remarkable statements, including saying Putin is a better leader than President Barack Obama to a June closed-door meeting of foreign policy Brahmins in Washington. In July, in Moscow, he spoke at the New Economic School鈥檚 commencement ceremony, a university that had hosted Obama just seven years ago. Page used the speech to slam the 鈥渉ypocrisy鈥?of American foreign policy in front of a Russian audience, saying, 鈥淲ashington and other Western powers have impeded potential progress through their often hypocritical focus on ideas such as democratization, inequality, corruption and regime change.鈥?He is now frequently quoted on Russian television, which hails him as a 鈥渇amous American economist鈥?and 鈥渁dviser to Donald Trump on questions of foreign policy.鈥?
All of which reveals something deeply strange about Trump: when he shoots from the hip, his remarks do more than just whip up Twitter controversies. They also occasionally and unintentionally mint a new species of 鈥渋nsiders,鈥?people who seem to be in Trump鈥檚 orbit but who may not have鈥攁nd may never have had鈥攁ny access to the gilded inner sanctum at all.

But someone is paying attention. As I started looking into Page, I began getting calls from two separate 鈥渃orporate investigators鈥?digging into what they claim are all kinds of shady connections Page has to all kinds of shady Russians. One is working on behalf of various unnamed Democratic donors; the other won鈥檛 say who turned him on to Page鈥檚 scent. Both claimed to me that the FBI was investigating Page for allegedly meeting with Igor Sechin and Sergei Ivanov, who was until recently Putin鈥檚 chief of staff鈥攂oth of whom are on the sanctions list鈥攚hen Page was in Moscow in July for that speech.

So the question continued to linger: Who is Carter Page?

***

I should tell you before we get any further that Page wouldn鈥檛 talk to me for this story. I called his fund and left messages, both on the general line and his personal voice mail. I emailed him repeatedly. I asked the Trump campaign to put me in touch. I emailed the Bloomberg journalist who interviewed him, who passed the request on. I even called Carter Page鈥檚 father in Poughkeepsie, New York, who told me he would ask his son to talk to me. But alas, no dice.

This was disappointing: No one who worked in Moscow when Page was there seemed to know who he was, and I just wanted to talk to someone who did. At a certain point, I just needed confirmation that he even existed.

OK, I thought. Try a different route. Maybe all these prominent Western businessmen who worked in Russia for decades didn鈥檛 know Page, but maybe it was because some of them worked in different spheres of the Russian economy. He did, after all, have such an impressive r茅sum茅.

Page鈥檚 biography on the website of his energy fund, Global Energy Capital, hits all the right notes. It was, at first glance, the r茅sum茅 of an up-and-coming player in the opaque but lucrative Russian energy market. 鈥淗e spent 7 years as an investment banker at Merrill Lynch in London, Moscow and New York where he most recently served as Chief Operating Officer of the Energy and Power Group,鈥?his bio reads. 鈥淗e was involved in over $25 billion of transactions in the energy and power sector. He spent 3 years in Moscow where he was responsible for the opening of the Merrill office and was an advisor on key transactions for Gazprom, RAO UES and others.鈥?
Those were some of the biggest energy deals of the 2000s, and Page鈥檚 tenure in Merrill Lynch鈥檚 Moscow office, from 2004 to 2007, would have put him in the right place at the right time. He says he was part of the carving up of RAO UES, a massive Russian electric power holding company. He told Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom when it bought a stake in the Sakhalin II oil and gas project. Those were huge, huge things. If he were deeply involved, he would definitely count as a player. And surely he left at least a trace in the records of those deals.

So I called Ian Craig, the CEO of Sakhalin Energy from 2004 to 2009, who was doing the negotiations with Gazprom and stayed on as CEO after the deal went through. (It wasn鈥檛 really a deal, to be clear: Sakhalin II was a large project in the Far East, and Gazprom essentially elbowed its way into the project when the government forced the consortium to sell the gas giant a controlling stake.) But Craig said he didn鈥檛 know anyone named Carter Page. He was also surprised to hear about Merrill Lynch鈥檚 purported involvement in the deal. 鈥淚 don鈥檛 think Merrill Lynch or anyone else was front-lining the negotiations, because it was all done at the highest level, because it was very political,鈥?says Craig . 鈥淚t closed at CEO level, and eventually Putin himself signed off on it.鈥?
When I asked a prominent Western businessman, who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades and who is said to socialize with Sechin and other members of the Russian elite, about Page鈥檚 claim to Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom on Sakhalin II, he said, 鈥淚 rolled my eyes at that one.鈥?(He, too, said he hadn鈥檛 heard of Page until Trump鈥檚 announcement.)

Fine. OK. Maybe Page exaggerated a bit on that one. But what about the reorganization and privatization of RAO UES, the Russian electricity giant? Maybe some of the Russians he worked with remembered a Carter Page?

Turns out, they did.

鈥淗is nickname was stranichkin,鈥?from the Russian word stranichka, or 鈥渓ittle page,鈥?says Artem Torchinsky, who met Page during the breakup of RAO UES. Torchinsky, who was part of the company鈥檚 financial department, worked alongside Page, who, at the time worked in Merrill Lynch鈥檚 Moscow office. It was 2007, and Merrill Lynch was underwriting the sale of one part of RAO UES, and Torchinsky was resentful of Page and the other Merrill Lynchers: Torchinsky and the in-house team did all the work, and Page and his team would swoop in to give the presentation. They were the fancy Western window dressing. 鈥淚t really irritated our team,鈥?Torchinsky told me over Skype. 鈥淲e worked around the clock, and then they would come in and say something incomprehensible and we鈥檇 have to correct them. These guys didn鈥檛 know what they were talking about.鈥?As for Page, 鈥淗e made no impression whatsoever. Whether he was there or not, it made no difference,鈥?Torchinsky says. 鈥淲hen you鈥檙e dealing with a pro, you see it. Page, unfortunately, did not leave that impression.鈥?
OK, harsh. But then I talked to Page鈥檚 former boss, former Russian Central Bank Chairman Sergei Aleksashenko, who ran the Moscow office of Merrill Lynch for part of the time Page worked there. 鈥淗e wasn鈥檛 great and he wasn鈥檛 terrible,鈥?Aleksashenko says, exasperated and confused by the interest of all these journalists pestering him for information about someone 鈥渨ithout any special talents or accomplishments,鈥?someone who was 鈥渁 gray spot.鈥?鈥淲hat can you say about a person who in no way [is] exceptional?鈥?he asked me.

Page was a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Moscow, which sounds senior but is a common title in the finance world; a big firm like Merrill Lynch might have thousands of VPs. In the Moscow office, there were five ranks, and VP was right in the middle. In effect, it was 鈥渏ust the oldest of the youngest, three from the bottom,鈥?says Aleksashenko.

When it came to finance, Aleksashenko says, Page 鈥渨as not a specialist in any branches of finance or in any instruments.鈥?When it came to energy, Page and his team were, according to Torchinsky, 鈥渕ildly speaking, not competent in the field of energy.鈥?And, says Aleksashenko, 鈥渏udging by the drivel he spews on Russia, you can tell he doesn鈥檛 really understand the topic.鈥?
Trump鈥檚 putative adviser on Russia and energy and foreign policy, in other words, 鈥渄id not create the impression of someone who was intellectual or well-educated, or someone who was in any way interested or knowledgeable in foreign policy,鈥?says Aleksashenko.

***

For the past few years, Page has styled himself a foreign policy expert. He has written columns in Global Policy Journal, a new peer-reviewed journal run out of Durham University. They are confoundingly written and make logically curious leaps. 鈥淚n recent months, renewed calls for equal justice have brought social tension across the United States after the killing of Michael Brown and Eric Garner by police officers in Missouri and New York respectively,鈥?he wrote. 鈥淎lthough commonly overlooked, the impact of other fatal mistakes by government officials in the foreign policy arena might vastly outweigh these tragic deaths in potentially catastrophic proportions.鈥?He is the kind of thinker who writes that Kanye West鈥檚 鈥淣ew Slaves鈥?and the 鈥渁rtist鈥檚 creative work offers valuable ideas that could fundamentally improve the direction of U.S. foreign policy and world affairs鈥?but does it by opening with a citation from the Oxford English Dictionary (鈥淪lave; Pronunciation: /sl膩v/鈥︹€?, roping in Adam Sandler, William F. Buckley and Dick Cheney.

His speech in Moscow鈥檚 New Economic School was a similar construction of empty spaces held together with repetition, tautologies, and abuses of the word 鈥渋ronically.鈥?鈥淔or the last 15 years, I鈥檝e been researching, teaching, and writing about fundamental trends in the world economy, which have really continued to evolve in this period and in the years immediately preceding it,鈥?he began. The video of the speech also suggests that after three years living there and a lifetime studying the place, he couldn鈥檛 really speak Russian鈥攈e had to have his questions translated for him into English. Except to quote, haltingly, brokenly, Vladimir Putin: 鈥淲e never meddle in the internal political affairs of other countries. Unlike the USA.鈥?Which is troubling for two reasons: that the adviser of a presidential candidate of a major party is criticizing America abroad by citing Putin, and that the comment implied that he seemed to not know anything about anything going on in, say, Syria or Ukraine.

Page also managed to find his way into a fellowship at the Council on Foreign Relations, where he cut a strange figure. Like other Westerners doing business in Russia, Page took the view that Putin was not the blood-stained and corrupt tyrant some in the West imagine him to be, defending him as a strong leader who brought order and prosperity to Russia. But unlike other entrepreneurial defenders of Putin, people at the Council recall that Page was not particularly good at it. 鈥淗e had a guilty-seeming style in making these arguments, making it seem like he didn鈥檛 really want to engage,鈥?one person from the Council says. His columns made the rounds and raised eyebrows. 鈥淭hat blog post about the slaves. That鈥檚 just 鈥?strange,鈥?says the Council member.

鈥淗e鈥檚 a nice guy, but of the people that I know that have Russian foreign policy experience or access and contacts, he wouldn鈥檛 be in the last decile, but he鈥檇 be in the second-to-last decile,鈥?says one American executive with experience in Russia and its energy sector. 鈥淵ou鈥檇 have to dip really far and wide to find a guy like Carter Page. I mean, wow.鈥?
***

I should鈥檝e just dropped the Carter Page story, but in the months since Trump named him an adviser, the campaign鈥檚 Russia connections have become a bigger and bigger issue. Fancy Bear, who was probably a Russian hacker, broke into the Democratic National Committee emails, seemingly handed them over to Julian Assange, who continues to leak the information in a way that is clearly designed to help one campaign and hurt the other. Trump鈥檚 second campaign manager, Paul Manafort, flamed out in August because of his shady business dealings with the pro-Kremlin side of Ukraine, and Trump himself continues to say absurd things about Russia and Putin, like publicly inviting the Russian government to continue hacking American servers. Washington was in full Hunt for Red October mode, and it was all I could do to stay on Page鈥檚 trail, which began to look more and more like an infinity sign.

I was not the only one. Seemingly everyone I talked to had also talked to the Washington Post, and then there were these corporate investigators who drew a dark and complex web of Page鈥檚 connections. Then there was Page, praising Putin. I found myself juggling two mutually contradictory Page narratives: Was Page, like Manafort, followed by a long train of sordid dealings with dark and powerful players with deep pockets and deep resentments toward the West? This was the person described by the corporate investigators trying to whisper into my ear. Was Page a man wheeling and dealing in energy contracts with China and Turkmenistan, who was a vehicle for the Kremlin to influence the American election? Was he a man who, during a three-day trip to Moscow, met with two of Russia鈥檚 most powerful men and was now being investigated for it?

But it was hard to see that man when I actually talked to people who knew him. Page made his way into the financial sector as it ballooned in the early part of the past decade, securing a spot at Merrill Lynch鈥檚 London and Moscow offices. Today, he claims he was cozy with Gazprom executives; his former colleagues laugh at the suggestion. 鈥淣o one let him into Gazprom,鈥?Aleksashenko says. 鈥淗e didn鈥檛 go shake [Gazprom chief Alexey] Miller鈥檚 hand. He made sure there were cars, hotels and meetings for investors in London.鈥?Another of Page鈥檚 colleagues from Merrill Lynch confirmed that Page鈥檚 role was simply arranging meetings between Gazprom and Western investors, something normally done by analysts, the lowest rank on the totem pole. 鈥淧eople organize meetings with Gazprom all the time,鈥?the former colleague said. 鈥淗e hosted these guys in New York City but they would have done this 10 times a year鈥?I used to do this; it doesn鈥檛 require all that much skill. You just send out an email to 20 people saying Gazprom agreed to dinner at this place at 8 p.m., do you want to come? The main thing is just getting those two [Gazprom] guys to agree. But because they agreed doesn鈥檛 mean they鈥檙e close to him.鈥?
But the meetings did provide him with something else. 鈥淕azprom didn鈥檛 need money at the time,鈥?says the former colleague. 鈥淭hey were the most profitable company at the time. Their net profit was something like $36 billion a year. Their problem was not getting investors, but figuring out how to spend money in a non-efficient way if you read between the lines. He was probably aware of that. He would have known how inefficient and wasteful the company is.鈥?Page became an investor in the company, and has, according to filings, advised other companies he鈥檚 worked for to invest in them.

After Merrill Lynch, Page tried to set up his own fund to invest in energy projects and called it Global Energy Capital. But he tried to do this in 2008, and we know what happened to the markets in 2008. The fund is registered to his father鈥檚 address in Poughkeepsie; Page listed himself as 鈥渇ounder and managing partner,鈥?even though the only other partner seemed to be Sergei Yatsenko, who was once a mid-level executive at Gazprom. He also maintained a website and handed out business cards that listed a fancy Madison Avenue address鈥攖hat鈥檚 the one 鈥渁round the corner from Trump Tower鈥濃€?which was actually the address of a co-working space.

鈥淭hat鈥檚 Carter Page,鈥?says an American businessman who has spent nearly a decade working in Russia. 鈥淭hat鈥檚 what he鈥檚 been doing, without any actual funding, without any actual experience, without any actual connections or core capabilities, he鈥檚 been trying to throw together these deals. He鈥檚 always been operating at a level far beneath that at which business in Russia is done. I admire that, it takes a lot of gumption.鈥?
In the interest of due diligence, I also tried to run down the rumors being handed me by the corporate investigators: that Russia鈥檚 Alfa Bank paid for the trip as a favor to the Kremlin; that Page met with Sechin and Ivanov in Moscow; that he is now being investigated by the FBI for those meetings because Sechin and Ivanov were both sanctioned for Russia鈥檚 invasion of Ukraine.

鈥淚 don鈥檛 know this person,鈥?said Pyotr Aven, one of the two founders of Alfa Bank, which is considered the Western Russian bank. Aven and his partner, Mikhail Fridman, have transferred much of their assets out of Russia and have been quite critical of Putin. As for who paid for Page鈥檚 trip, Aven was no less irritated by the question. 鈥淚 give them money, I don鈥檛 know how they spend it, who they invite, when they invite them, I have no idea,鈥?he said of the New Economic School, which hosted Page and of which Aven is the main benefactor. Exasperated by my questions, he snapped, 鈥淒on鈥檛 bring these Russian-style conspiracy theories to me.鈥?
鈥淵ou are engaged in onanism,鈥?said Leontiev, the spokesman for Rosneft and Sechin when I asked him if Page had met with Sechin. 鈥淚t鈥檚 bullshit. Just bullshit. You need to understand who Sechin is to even ask this question. It鈥檚 hard to have a meeting with him at all. It鈥檚 absurd.鈥?
As for the FBI investigation, well, it鈥檚 unclear. A State Department official who works on Russia sanctions but was not authorized to speak on the record told me that, for one thing, there is 鈥渘o prohibition meeting with a designated [sanctioned] individual. Moreover, sanctions violations are not criminal in nature and not enforced by the FBI. OFAC runs them.鈥?He added, 鈥渢he story doesn't add up.鈥?What does seem to have happened is that various U.S. intelligence agencies were looking into Page鈥檚 time in Moscow, then briefed Senate minority leader, Democrat Harry Reid, who wrote a letter to FBI Director James Comey asking him to investigate, among other things, 鈥渨hether a Trump advisor who has been highly critical of U.S. and European economic sanctions on Russia, and who has conflicts of interest due to investments in Russian energy conglomerate Gazprom, met with high-ranking sanctioned individuals while in Moscow in July of 2016, well after Trump became the presumptive Republican nominee.鈥?
***

I got my next surprise when I called Stephen Miller, Trump鈥檚 senior adviser. I caught him just as the Trump plane was about to take off, and asked him the tired, old question: Who is Carter Page?

鈥淲ho?鈥?says Miller, and then went off the record to expound on his lack of involvement in the campaign.

鈥淗e has no formal role in the campaign,鈥?Hope Hicks texted responding to my question.

Now my interest was piqued. There were whispers all over Washington that, despite Hicks鈥檚 denial, Page was not only still part of the Trump campaign, but its conduit for Russian influence. Was he?

One way to answer the question was to figure out how he even got on that list to begin with.

One source suggested to me that Richard Burt, former U.S. ambassador to Germany, START treaty negotiator, and longtime lobbyist for Alfa Bank, was the nexus. It was Burt who helped draft Trump鈥檚 foreign policy speech in April, and had been advising the Trump campaign, via Senator Jeff Sessions, on foreign policy. But when I met Burt at his office at the McLarty Associates lobbying shop, he looked at me and said he had never even met him. 鈥淭he only person I talked to about Carter Page is this guy at the Washington Post,鈥?Burt told me. 鈥淎nd I told him I鈥檇 never met the guy. Let me put it this way: if I have met him, I鈥檝e forgotten. He鈥檚 the former Merrill Lynch guy, right?鈥?
Someone else told me that the Page connection was Rick Dearborn, Sessions鈥?chief of staff, who hired Page because Dearborn knew nothing about foreign policy but needed to put together a foreign policy staff for Trump鈥檚 Alexandria, Virginia, policy shop and he happened to know Page. But Dearborn wouldn鈥檛 return my calls, and someone who once worked for that policy shop told me it was neither Dearborn nor Burt, but campaign co-chair Sam Clovis who recruited Page. 鈥淚f he was part of that original group of people, I can say with 70 percent confidence it was Sam Clovis,鈥?this person told me.

鈥淚鈥檓 not answering your questions,鈥?Clovis told me. He refused to tell me if he was the one who found Page, but Jason Miller, the campaign鈥檚 other spokesperson, says, 鈥淐arter Page isn鈥檛 someone I鈥檝e interacted with.鈥?Which confirmed what a policy staffer on the Trump campaign told me: 鈥淐arter is a red herring, not a Rasputin. He鈥檚 never met Trump, never briefed him. He has zero influence, none.鈥?
***

Was Page the shadowy messenger between the Kremlin and Trump Tower, or was he the nebbishy, not-very-successful man trying to profit from the arbitrage between what Trump said鈥攈e鈥檚 my adviser鈥攁nd what his associates said鈥斺€淲ho?鈥?Maybe I wasn鈥檛 doing this right, and maybe everyone was lying to me, but it was hard not to come to the conclusion that, regardless of whatever game the Russians were running, Page was firmly in the latter camp.

鈥淚 don鈥檛 know about his Russia fund, other than it鈥檚 never really materialized,鈥?says the prominent player in the energy space whom Page has pitched on various energy projects. 鈥淓very conversation I鈥檝e had with Carter has not been terribly serious. They鈥檝e all been pie-in-the-sky ideas. There are usually issues with traction and execution capabilities.鈥?He went on. 鈥淚 couldn鈥檛 name a project that I could connect Carter鈥檚 name to, any project that actually happened.鈥?
鈥淚 don鈥檛 know how he鈥檚 earned a living off this,鈥?the energy player says, 鈥渂ut I think he鈥檚 been trying to be an intermediary. If you hang around Russia long enough, it鈥檚 sort of like a pinball machine, something will hit you.鈥?
Strangely, it was not a Russian pinball that hit him; it was Trump. According to the Trump policy adviser, this winter, Clovis began to draw up a list of people who could serve as policy advisers to the campaign and give it some intellectual and policy heft. At a time when established Republican foreign policy specialists were tripping over each other to get away from Trump, 鈥渁 lot of people came to Sam Clovis in February, March, and said, 鈥業 want to be part of the team,鈥欌€?says the Trump adviser. And that鈥檚 how it happened. 鈥淗e鈥檚 just a guy on a list. Trump looked at the list and said, 鈥楬e鈥檚 an adviser.鈥?And now he鈥檚 milking it for all it鈥檚 worth.鈥?
Now, someone whom no one in the field had ever heard of was suddenly a Very Important Person in Washington鈥攐r at least could plausibly market himself as one. 鈥淚 was not aware of him at all until he was named to the campaign, and even after that, I had never heard of him,鈥?one Russia specialist in Washington told me. He saw Page at a Washington roundtable in June for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and what he saw was a strange kind of person: one who was very differential to everyone there 鈥渋n a way that someone who is junior would use it to network,鈥?but who was dropping hints full of meaning to anyone who would listen鈥攁nd be impressed. 鈥淗e was saying he was planning to go to Moscow,鈥?the Russia specialist recalls. 鈥淗e didn鈥檛 say what he was going to do there, but he created the impression that there could be some meaning to the trip.鈥?
According to a congressional leadership staffer familiar with the intelligence briefings on Page鈥檚 trip to Russia, 鈥渢he meetings did happen and that鈥檚 been established as a fact. I think the investigation is more what happened in them.鈥?But it remained unclear, the staffer told me unprompted, what this even meant. 鈥淚t鈥檚 not just did he met with them or not, but now looking into the bigger question of what the hell is going on?鈥?said the staffer. 鈥淚s he acting as a conduit in ways that are against America鈥檚 national security interests? Wittingly or un-, I should add. It鈥檚 what鈥檚 hard to parse about this. Is he doing this with nefarious intent or is this just about guys who are thrilled to be living in a John le Carr茅 novel? Or are they being played by much smarter people in the Kremlin?鈥?
This seems to be vintage Carter Page, a man whose story never quite adds up, as much as he tries to make the numbers work. But he鈥檚 also mastered the art of manipulating the distance between his story as it is and his story as he wants it to be, playing on the uncertainty in between to make himself seem more successful, more connected, even more evil than he really is鈥攁nd to try to turn a profit off of that. 鈥淚f Page using his status as 鈥楾rump advisor鈥?for personal gain, that鈥檚 another matter: Time for Page to join Twitter!鈥?Michael McFaul, former U.S. ambassador to Russia, tweeted after news of the investigation broke. The Russians may be feeling out the Trump campaign via Page, but Page must be loving every minute of it. After all, meeting Russia鈥檚 energy czar is an impossible dream for a would-be investor struggling to make it in the world of Russian energy鈥攂ut the dream entered the realm of the possible when Trump said three words in March: 鈥淐arter Page, Ph.D.鈥?Now Carter Page, Ph.D., has found a perfect candidate to latch on to, like a pilot fish feeding off the carnage wrought by the oblivious Trump shark.

For months now, the American press has been twisting itself in knots trying to explain men like Page and Manafort, and, through them, to answer the questions of whether Putin is trying to destroy America by their hands, and is Trump a Kremlin stooge or a just a useful idiot, and is there even a difference?

There doesn鈥檛 seem to be one in the world of Trump, which in some ways resembles Putin鈥檚: the waters of truth are muddy and deeply suggestive. And that is all that matters. Is Putin actually meddling in our election and undermining the foundations of Western democracy in a massive way, or doing just enough to make us think he is, and thereby acquiring powers he holds only because we believe him to have them? 鈥淚 want to hope that this is connected with the growing influence and significance of Russia,鈥?Putin says of the rumors of Russian meddling in the American election鈥攁s we in the media continue to squeegee them around, rarely really getting closer to the truth, and watching it disintegrate in our hands when we think we鈥檝e finally grasped it.

Julia Ioffe is contributing writer at Politico Magazine.

Oddly, nobody in Russia seems to have heard of him.', 'og': {'site_name': 'POLITICO Magazine', 'description': 'Reports of deep Russian ties swirl around Trump adviser Carter Page. Oddly, nobody in Russia seems to have heard of him.', 'title': 'The Mystery of Trump鈥檚 Man in Moscow', 'url': 'http://politi.co/2crBNwG', 'image': 'http://static.politico.com/47/07/5255ce914040a7a0ca8aea7482f0/carter-page-ap-1160.jpg', 'fb_appid': 114037015331397, 'type': 'article'}, 'twitter': {'site': '@politicomag', 'card': 'summary_large_image', 'creator': '@politicomag'}, 'host': 'www.politico.com', 'fb': {'pages': 62317591679}, 'build': 'release/2017-maria 4b1f874 2017-08-24T15:20:21Z', 'viewport': 'width=device-width, initial-scale=1'}
column8: The Mystery of Trump鈥檚 Man in Moscow: Carter Page

column2:
Like much of the mainstream media, the Washington Post is going out of its way to disparage Donald Trump. But the Post isn鈥檛 satisfied with the normal biased reporting鈥攖hey have gone above and beyond assigning 20 reporters just to dig up dirt on the Republican nominee. That must have failed because now they are taking the lazy, but disgusting way out with inappropriate Hitler references. Twice in this month Post columnists have compared Donald Trump to Adolf Hitler. Perhaps the editors have designated September as 鈥淭rump Is Hitler Month鈥?at the Washington Post.

On Monday they featured a column by Richard Cohen which said in part,

(鈥? while Trump is neither an anti-Semite nor does he have designs on neighboring countries, he is Hitlerian in his thinking. He thinks the truth is what he says it is.

Mr. Cohen didn鈥檛 mention what despot Hillary鈥檚 lies reminded him of, but then again the post would never have a 鈥淗illary is Hitler month.鈥?While a Hillary comparison would be just as wrong, the fact that they are only creating a 鈥淭rump鈥?month is incredibly sexist.

Six Day鈥檚 before Mr. Cohen, another columnist Shalom Auslander wrote, 鈥淒on鈥檛 compare Donald Trump to Adolf Hitler. It belittles鈥?
The views expressed in this opinion article are solely those of their author and are not necessarily either shared or endorsed by EagleRising.com

column8: It鈥檚 鈥淭rump is HITLER鈥?Month at the Washington Post 鈥?Eagle Rising

column2:
2016 Obama鈥檚 team isn鈥檛 laughing at Trump anymore The president鈥檚 aides worry the Republican represents more of America than a fringe.

Obamaworld laughed as it watched Donald Trump鈥檚 hostile takeover of the GOP. After eight years of Republican opposition, inconsistent policy demands and racialized hate against the first black president, President Barack Obama鈥檚 aides, past and present, thought Republicans had gotten what they deserved--and more, all but forfeiting the 2016 race to the woman they defeated eight years ago.

They鈥檙e not laughing anymore.

Story Continued Below

Going into Monday night鈥檚 debate, Obama鈥檚 team is feeling that same anxiety expressed by some top Hillary Clinton aides: maybe the country isn鈥檛 what they thought, maybe the resistance to Obamacare and gay marriage and the progress they鈥檙e so proud of is broader than the vocal fringe they鈥檝e always dismissed. Maybe, the president鈥檚 aides 鈥?current and former 鈥?now concede, they鈥檙e going to have to live with the fact that Trump could end up in the Oval Office in part due to a backlash against Obama.

鈥淚鈥檓 trying to think of a series to compare it to, which was a series that started as a comedy and became a high stakes drama,鈥?said Ben LaBolt, a former White House aide and press secretary for Obama鈥檚 2012 reelection campaign. 鈥淚 feel like we鈥檙e maybe in the fifth season of 鈥楤reaking Bad鈥?here. We鈥檙e way beyond the laughs, and just sitting on the edge of our seats in terror.鈥?
鈥淭here's not a lot of mirth in the circles I run in about him,鈥?said another former senior Obama campaign staffer.

Privately, Obama has expressed mixed feelings, according to people close to the president. He鈥檚 still nursing amusement at Republicans for being hapless enough to get railroaded by Trump, but it鈥檚 mixed with frustration that there are so many Americans he failed to reach. People who've spoken to him say the president wonders what he might have done differently to break through in a way that would make people who鈥檝e benefited from his policies鈥攍ike those enjoying added health benefits courtesy of Obamacare鈥攕upport Democrats.

For Obamaworld staffers who had just been starting to settle into a new buoyancy about the president's climbing approval numbers, Trump鈥檚 growing strength is an agonizing reminder of how far short they have fallen in delivering on 鈥榟ope.' Even if Clinton wins, the Republican has shown not only that America is divided between red and blue but that there鈥檚 an America that Obama never connected with at all, and where all his data and rational arguments and appeals to sensibilities are as useless as Monopoly money.

鈥淲e are still the country that elected Barack Obama in 2008, and we are capable of that and more,鈥?said Jim Papa, a former special assistant for legislative affairs in the White House. 鈥淏ut we鈥檙e also capable of making bad choices and being seduced by someone who plays to fears and anxieties and racial differences.鈥?
Trump鈥檚 already done things they never thought he could, like mainstreaming racist rhetoric and racking up so many small donors that they worry about the extent of his support. And that was even before he riled up Obama doubters again with his birther pirouette.

And the result: Trump鈥檚 doing better in the polls at this late stage than Obama鈥檚 team imagined. With 43 days to go, Trump and Clinton are essentially tied, polls sitting within the margin of error, even in battleground states.

Though only a few weeks ago, current and former Obama aides would joke about how the president鈥檚 great political legacy might be the Republican Party destroying itself in front of him. Now, on the record, they push back on the very suggestion that Obama鈥檚 legacy should be viewed in any frame that Trump also occupies.

鈥淚 don鈥檛 think he thinks it鈥檚 his legacy, I don鈥檛 think any of us think it鈥檚 his legacy,鈥?said Dan Pfeiffer, a former senior adviser to the president. 鈥淭rumpism is a lot of things in this country. President Obama is the face of that for some Republicans, but the Republican Party got themselves into this mess.鈥?
But they worry about what even a Trump loss says about Obama鈥檚 America.

鈥淚 think he will lose badly in this election, but I think the impact he鈥檚 had on our political process is incredibly damaging, and will be lasting,鈥?said Tommy Vietor, a former national security spokesman who noted that his own amusement at Trump ended a year ago. 鈥淗e鈥檚 made us look stupid. I think he is stupid.鈥?
For any efforts Obama made in urging people to disagree without being disagreeable, as the president likes to say, 鈥淭rump has shattered that,鈥?Vietor said. 鈥淗e has brought back a brand of politics that is you punch your opponent as hard as you can, it doesn鈥檛 matter if it鈥檚 a low blow, it doesn鈥檛 matter if it鈥檚 not of substance. That鈥檚 a bad lesson for people to learn.鈥?
According to Earnest, Obama is serious about wanting a functional opposition and wishes that he鈥檇 had one to negotiate with on immigration reform, trade, infrastructure and other priorities. The sense of lost opportunity eats at them, as does the sense that it鈥檚 not going away, despite their confidence in Clinton鈥檚 chances.

鈥淚鈥檓 not saying we鈥檇 all be playing acoustic guitar in a circle on the National Mall, but I am saying we would have progress to show for our efforts,鈥?said White House press secretary Josh Earnest, who's been with the president since the first campaign.

Not everyone鈥檚 inside Obamaworld is down. Some schadenfreude remains.

鈥淗e's still exposed and ripped apart factions of the GOP, enhanced their brand as hostile to a rising electorates, and will leave them with no infrastructure,鈥?said a more upbeat former Obama 2008 campaign spokesman Hari Sevugan.

And Democrats鈥?sense of the vacuous GOP that Trump represents continues to resonate, particularly as they see the Republican nominee attack an economy that鈥檚 gone wrong with the support of many of the same people who opposed the policies that the president credits for the economic rebound that includes the longest period of sustained growth and taxpayers repaid with interest from the bailouts that caused so much trouble.

鈥淭he eight-year legacy of the recovery from the Great Recession is clear evidence that the Tea Party movement,鈥?said Earnest, 鈥渋s intellectually bankrupt鈥攐r about something other than the economy.鈥?
But that doesn't take care of their grief about the state of American politics.

鈥淚鈥檇 rather live in a world where the two parties really compete,鈥?Papa said, 鈥渢han have a political edge on the Republican Party but have to live in a world where white supremacists have a channel and are legitimized.鈥?

column2:
There may be a few women out there who enjoy a man telling them to be more joyous in their presence, but as for the rest of us, there鈥檚 nothing a woman hates more than being told to smile.

Do men smile all the time? No. Because if they did, we鈥檇 think they were crazy and up to something. Same goes for women.

Not every situation calls for a smile at all times. Especially when discussing foreign policy and our military. So, when RNC Chair Reince Priebus thought it appropriate to criticize Hillary Clinton for not smiling enough during the NBC forum hosted by Matt Lauer, it didn鈥檛 exactly go over well.

One person who definitely had a lot to say about Priebus and his request of a smile from Hillary was none other than Chelsea Handler on her hit Netflix show Chelsea.

Chelsea began by asking Priebus:

鈥淲ho the f*ck are you to tell someone to smile?鈥?
Adding:

鈥淭his is just another example of how men feel the can belittle every woman in the world and order up a smile.鈥?
Chelsea then said:

鈥淪top telling women to smile. We don鈥檛 like that. It鈥檚 not an icebreaker, it鈥檚 a deal breaker.鈥?
Going for Priebus鈥?jugular, Chelsea absolutely destroys him and his ridiculously corny smile, then says:

鈥淵ou know when women will smile? When Hillary kicks that pneumonia and trounces Trump in November.鈥?
And that鈥檚 exactly right.

Watch the full video here:

Featured image via video screen capture
